instruction: How were the machine learning algorithms (MLAs) compared in terms of their sensitivities to feature selection (FS) and the influence of FS on classification accuracy in the proposed procedure for land cover mapping (LCM) in complex surface-mined and agricultural landscapes using high spatial resolution satellite imagery?
Output:
In the proposed procedure for land cover mapping (LCM) in complex surface-mined and agricultural landscapes, three machine learning algorithms (MLAs) were compared in terms of their sensitivities to feature selection (FS) and the influence of FS on classification accuracy. The MLAs used in the study were random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), and artificial neural network (ANN).

The study found that FS substantially reduced the feature set for both LCM of surface-mined and agricultural landscapes (MSMAL) and classification of surface-mined land (CSML). FS reduced the feature set by 68% for MSMAL and 87% for CSML. Additionally, FS often improved classification accuracies. For MSMAL, the average improvement in accuracy using three MLAs was 4.48%, while for CSML, the improvement using RF and SVM was 11.39%.

The study also examined the sensitivity of the MLAs to FS. It was found that SVM was the most sensitive to FS, followed by ANN and RF. This means that SVM was more affected by the feature selection process compared to the other two algorithms.
